metadata.synopsis: After the melting of the polar ice caps, most of the globe is underwater. Some humans have survived, and even fewer still, notably the Mariner (Kevin Costner), have adapted to the ocean by developing gills. A loner by nature, the Mariner reluctantly befriends Helen (Jeanne Tripplehorn) and her young companion, Enola (Tina Majorino), as they escape from a hostile artificial island. Soon the sinister Smokers are pursuing them in the belief that Enola holds the key to finding the mythical Dryland.

reviews: My Kevin Costner gettin' all Mad Max on a turbo jet-ski beats your Eddie Murphy goin' through the motions.
A very dignified production with some tremendously stimulating ideas that, yes, were not entirely well exposed in the movie that came to theaters two decades ago. [Full Review in Spanish]
Waterworld may not be a masterpiece, but it is certainly a shining example of large scale entertainment as only Hollywood can deliver.

That Costner's antihero should be so fundamentally dislikable is entirely acceptable - after all, the Mariner's arc makes him an eternal outsider... - but that he should also be deadly dull is less so
The unfairly maligned Kostner vehicle is much better than its reputation
Offers a true extravaganza of epic proportions, populating its world with colourful characters and genuinely thrilling spectacle in equal measure.
Costner... is totally humorless and as dreary as the landscape he travels. And the uninspired and often inane dialogue in Peter Rader and David Twohy's script doesn't help.
Waterworld is a pretty damn good summer movie. There, I've said it...it's a breezy, clever entertainment with stirring effects.
Waterworld is a mess masquerading as a movie. Setting out to do something startlingly new, it ends up stunningly familiar.
It's borderline halfway decent. For the first 25 minutes or so, it's even actually good, in its derivative way.
Regardless of faults, I embrace Waterworld as the pure matinee escapism it was intended to be, readily devouring the sci-fi excitement both Reynolds and Costner are happy to dish up.
While it is true that time, and the obsessive culture of the Internet, has lessened Waterworld's "Fishtar" reputation to some extent, this is still one massively flawed film.
Waterworld drowned in bad buzz during its theatrical release. It deserves a better fate.
I had no idea what the characters were thinking half the time, but I had an excellent idea what they were feeling, physically.
